page.title: 17Clipping-how it's done
page.content: Three men were at work, shearing with electric clippers. Each shearer caught his own sheep, took it out of the pen to a board laid on the ground to keep the wool clean. Here he turned the ewe until she was sitting on her rump supported by his legs. Taking the shears he began with the belly wool then the tail. Starting at the neck, he made long, sweeping strokes over the sides towards the tail. When one side and the back were sheared, he turned the ewe and continued on the other side. The fleece fell to the floor. A dab of red keel and the ewe was released. The shearer spread out the fleece, turned in the edges and rolled it - clean side in- into a neat bundle secured by a twist of wool. The whole process had taken 2 minutes 28 seconds.
